reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s suggestion that hitting a narrow “mostly-great” target would likely require deliberate optimization/steering. That’s somewhat connected to the essay’s upshot, but not central to the core thesis (“eutopia is fragile / the target is narrow”); the essay does not propose specific steering institutions or emergency powers, and explicitly defers the steering question to a later essay. As a result, centrality is low-moderate. The critique’s refutational force is weak: it largely asserts (without argument) that any steering institution will be captured and redefine eutopia, and it imputes a policy program (“indefinite emergency powers”) not defended in the text. Some underlying concerns (institutional capture risks, power misuse) are plausible in general, but the critique overstates them (“immediately captured by sociopaths”) and relies on a strawman reading, so correctness is limited. It is clearly written, focused on one issue, and contains little dead-weight despite being rhetorically loaded.
title: Institutions tasked with moral steering will be captured and corrupted
